text:
sawaddee ka welcome to hot thai kitchen i am 
back home in bangkok thailand and i'm going

to remake an old video that i made few years ago 
when i was back home in thailand we are making

pag gaprao now pad is a stir-fry and gaprao is holy 
basil delicious easy dish super famous well-known

in north america and the reason why i waited till 
I got here to make it is because right here in our

place gaprao grows like wheat they're everywhere in 
Vancouver they're a little harder to find so we're

going to start by first picking gaprao right off 
the plant this is the gaprao plant or holy basil

now this one's nice and big so I want to show you 
this one but it is an older plant and in general

the younger the gaprao the more aromatic they 
tend to be so for this from this one I'm going

to pick sort of the younger leaves from the top 
and not so much the older ones and compared to

Thai basil holy Basil's got a peppery flavor 
whereas Thai basil has a really sweet floral

aroma if you can't find holy basil though Thai 
basil will be just as delicious I'm going to

start by making an herb paste and that's simply 
garlic and chilies so I'm going to start though I

have two kinds of chilies I'm going to start first 
with the spicier kind so this is well Thai chilies

a pretty no and it's smaller its spicier and the 
reason why I want to start with this because I

want to make sure this is really really fine 
if I start putting garlic and everything else

in it I could accidentally have a little piece 
of this and then you know it's bad news if you

get one in your mouth I'm putting a lot because I 
don't think these are that spicy and you know pack

up how you want to make it quite spicy so skin 
is fine chili skins are stubborn but you don't

want any you know big actual chunks of chilies 
in there now I'm going to add some garlic lots

of garlic here and I'm also adding a sec kind of 
chilly this is pretty phat and I've just roughly

chopped it so it's easier to pound but the big 
one looks like that and it's milder it's not

very spicy at all we use it a lot for garnish 
but in this dish I like to add it so that I can

get some chili flavor without the heat so now you 
want to get this down to just a rough paste into

our Bowl here and that is going to be the base 
of the stir-fry so the next thing I'm going to

do is mix up the sauce so I've got some oyster 
sauce right here and to this I am going to add

some soy sauce I like to add some fish sauce to 
this as well I think it makes it a little sharper

an oyster sauce soy sauce and fish glass is what I 
call the Trinity of surprise sauces these three in

really anything makes a delicious stir fry to make 
the color a little darker I like to add dark soy

sauce think of it as like molasses plus soy sauce 
that's what this is and it just gives a beautiful

dark color a little bit of water when we go to 
stir-fry it will need a little extra liquid and

also some sugar if I don't add the water I don't 
like to add the sugar because sugar will have a

hard time dissolving and just like fake soy sauce 
and that's it that's the sauce you can make Petka

pal with really any kind of meat you want but but 
the most common type is either chicken or pork so

I'm gonna do chicken today but I'm going to do 
ground chicken and I'm going to grind it myself

for two reasons I want a coarser grind and also 
ground chicken is not exactly easy to find here

sometimes they have it sometimes they don't so 
I've got here a mixture of chicken thigh and

chicken breast and I do that because you know this 
is what you can do when you make your own ground

meat you can customize your mix just cut it into 
small pieces just to get it going and then with a

big cleaver you don't have to have a cleaver this 
also work with a big chef's knife to start hacking

and once you've exhausted sort of the the first 
part you can flip it and this is why a cleaver

is useful you take it and flip and then if you 
go okay and you really don't have to get this

very fine you could even just do big pieces of 
chicken you don't have to do ground chicken so

I'll just bite size if you want other than that 
I've just got some vegetables so long beans

I've cut into shorter pieces and onions I've 
diced you can do Julian's if you want and just

FYI long beans look like this they're longer in 
Thailand tempeh are in Canada and they're bigger

too so but if you don't have this regular green 
beans are find these a little bit crunchy err

in nutty year I like these ok so I am out here 
in my beautiful outdoor kitchen and in Thailand

this is quite common there's an inside kitchen 
outside kitchen and the outside kitchens for

things that will smell and splatter and you 
know so you don't have so much cleanup to do

so in goes a little bit of vegetable oil and then 
I'm going to go in with my garlic and chili paste

right away you don't have to wait for the oil to 
get hot for this you let it cook until basically

the neighbour starts smelling your chilies and 
garlic okay you're infusing the oil with the

garlic and the spiciness of the chilies the oil 
be your vehicle to flavor everything else okay

once the garlic starts to brown a little bit go in 
with the chicken and now you're just trying to get

the chicken to not be in big clumps so my family 
uses a stainless steel lock but I really missed my

carbon steel wok nothing sticks to that but this 
works just fine okay so now the chicken is sort

of in smaller pieces I'm going to go in with the 
sauce and get that mixed up oh yeah it's looking

good now depending on how you like your beans and 
onions if you like them nice and soft you want to

add them early so maybe at the same time as the 
sauce but if you want them to be still crunchy

and al dente you can wait until the chicken is 
mostly done woah this stove is crazy hot holy

mother okay so now just until the chicken is 
done and the cameraman starts coughing that's

a good sign okay now I'm going to turn it off and 
then I'm going to add my basil I want to add the

basil when the heat is off just use the residual 
heat because you don't want to cook the basil to

death it turns black turns mushy and you just toss 
it you and the basil will look like you've added

too much but trust me after it will it won't be 
much and you really want all that flavor and that

is it look how beautiful that is so now that 
that's done you can just serve that with rice

but what I'm going to do is I'm going to turn it 
into Calcutta Hokkaido which means rice cut your

how guy with chicken and then tie you down which 
is a Thai style fried egg let's make the fried

egg when you fry an egg Thai style it's almost 
like deep-frying you want a lot of oil because

a lot of oil will make bubbly crispy edges and you 
want to get it hot and goes the egg and it should

bubble just like that mmm bubbly egg when I went 
to culinary school they always teach the French

style your eggs should never brown whatsoever 
and I'm like no I want it browned and crispy

if the egg sticks a little bit like it is doing 
right now usually once it's once it cooks it'll

release itself so don't rush it and that's it once 
you have golden brown edges you are done back and

I should say that cough like a hawk I head out 
is sort of a classic thing you would order at a

streetside restaurant you know for a quick lunch 
and that's why you know it's kind of a cool thing

to me so I've got my cow with just rice looks so 
good alright and then put your Chi Dow right on

you want to see them the egg a little bit and 
a great condiment for that is pregnant black

basically prick which is chilies and then fly 
which is fish sauce spiked up with a little bit

of garlic and also a squeeze of lime so that's 
a mix that I like to use it's good on everything

this one's not running anymore but it's still 
sort of gooey and what we call yang matome in

Thai which means it's wet but it's you know it's 
just that perfect consistency of moist and gooey

mmm such a great flavor it's it's simple but 
that holy basil really boosts it up and it's

got a flavor like nothing you've ever had again 
Thai base it would be just as delicious but if you

can get a hold of holy basil you really really 
have to try it so the recipe as always will be

on hot Thai Kitchen.com when you make this send 
me a photo Facebook Twitter or Instagram I'd love

to see them and I'll include some of them in my

to the show please subscribe and I will see
